cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where does the lincoln highway begin and end
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
The Lincoln Highway is one of the earliest transcontinental highways in the United States, established in 1913. It was designed to connect the East and West coasts of the country. The highway traditionally begins in Times Square, New York City, which represents the eastern terminus. From there, it stretches across various states and landscapes, ultimately reaching its western terminus in San Francisco, California. This route was significant in promoting automobile travel and the development of road infrastructure in the U.S.

Answer:
The Lincoln Highway begins in Times Square, New York City, and ends in San Francisco, California.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where does the lincoln highway begin and end
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Lincoln Highway was planned from Illinois state line to South Bend to Fort Wayne and the Ohio state line in 1913. In 1915, the highway opened and passed through downtown Fort Wayne on its route through Indiana. In 1917, Main Market route number 2 was the given number to the Lincoln Highway in Indiana. In the early 1920s, the Lincoln Highway was moved farther south between Valparaiso and Fort Wayne, to what is now known mostly as Old US\xa030, passing through Plymouth and Warsaw. The route became SR\xa02 from Ohio state line to South Bend, SR\xa01 from South Bend to Michigan state line. Then in 1924, the sections of the road that was part of the original Lincoln Highway was paved. The next few years the rest of the route was paved across Indiana, then in 1937 US\xa033 was created.\n', 'The western end of the Lincoln Highway in Indiana was at the Illinois state line. The Lincoln Highway headed east passing through Dyer, still heading east the Lincoln Highway headed north around Schererville. Leaving US\xa030 and heading east, running one mile north of US\xa030, through Merrillville. East of Merrillville Lincoln Highway rejoins US\xa030, before leaving US\xa030 west of Valparaiso.\n', 'Lincoln Highway in Indiana\n', 'Nebraska Highway 31 is a highway in Nebraska. The southern terminus is near Louisville at an intersection with Nebraska Highway 50. The northern terminus is near Kennard at an intersection with U.S. Highway 30. The highway serves as a main north–south highway in the western portion of the Omaha Metro Area.\n', 'The Lincoln Highway was planned in 1913 to run west to east across Indiana, including to South Bend and Fort Wayne. In 1915, the highway opened and passed through downtown Fort Wayne on its route through Indiana, and was assigned the designation of Main Market route number 2 in 1917. Further designations saw the route become SR\xa02 from the Illinois state line to Valparaiso, SR\xa044 Valparaiso to Fort Wayne and SR\xa02 from Fort Wayne to the Ohio state line. In the early 1920s, the Lincoln Highway was moved south between Valparaiso and Fort Wayne, to what is now known mostly as Old US\xa030, passing through Plymouth and Warsaw. A section of US\xa030 in Dyer known as the "ideal section" of the Lincoln Highway was opened in 1923 and rebuilt in the 1990s. In 1924, the sections of the road that were part of the original Lincoln Highway was paved, followed by the paving of the rest of US 30, which was commissioned in 1926. In 1927, a small realignment between Hanna and SR\xa029 (current US\xa035) took place. During the 1950s, US 30 in Fort Wayne was rerouted to Coliseum Boulevard, constructed as a "circumurban" highway to bypass Fort Wayne. But this "circumurban" route became an urban highway in its own right. In 1998, US\xa030 in Fort Wayne was again rerouted onto I-69 and I-469, bypassing most of Fort Wayne and New Haven on the north and east side of the two towns. The Coliseum Boulevard routing was assigned the SR 930 designation as a result, when INDOT could not give the route over to local control.\n', 'The Lincoln Highway was the first route to follow the corridor of US\xa030 in Ohio. The Lincoln Highway was established in 1913, following the current route of SR\xa0309 and SR\xa081. Improvements and realignment to the highway were planned in 1917 and was to start in the spring of 1918. The route was built to relieve some of the railroad congestion. The Lincoln Highway realignment project was completed in 1939 and moved the Lincoln Highway to the modern US\xa030 corridor. The Lincoln Highway in Ohio became known as SR\xa05 between Indiana state line and Mansfield, SR\xa010 between Mansfield and Wooster, and SR\xa05 between Wooster and Pennsylvania. In 1925, the Federal Highway Association was established and one year later US\xa030 was established. US\xa030 followed the current route of SR\xa0309. US\xa030 eastern terminus in Ohio was relocated to the West Virginia state line, in 1928. The route became divided in 1932, with US\xa030N taking the current alignment of US\xa030 and US\xa030S taking the current alignment of SR\xa0309.\n', 'This abandoned section of roadway was part of the original Lincoln Highway from 1913. It lies to the north of the Chicago Northwestern tracks which are immediately to the north of the Grand Junction Segment (see above). The Lincoln Highway route was moved north in eastern Greene County in 1914 so the Greene and Boone County segments of the highway would connect. The realignment also removed a couple of dangerous railroad crossings at the same time. This section of roadway survived that realignment, and remained part of the highway until 1922 when the right-of-way was shifted south of the railroad tracks and a new roadway was built. This realignment removed another railroad crossing at Grand Junction. There are three contributing resources to this historic district, two structures and one site. One of the structures is a concrete bridge that features concrete balustered guardrails. It was built by the Iowa Bridge Company in 1915 for $1,339. It replaced an older wooden span. A partially buried concrete driveway culvert is the other structure, and a section of the abandoned dirt roadway is the site. The roadway was never paved. The historic district is located on a farm and the former roadway and bridge are still used to move farm machinery.\n', 'In 1913, the Lincoln Highway Association, headed by entrepreneur Carl G. Fisher, chose the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway (at the southeast corner of Times Square) to be the Eastern Terminus of the Lincoln Highway. This was the first road across the United States, which originally spanned coast-to-coast through 13 states to its western terminus in Lincoln Park in San Francisco, California.\n', "As defined in 1913, the Lincoln Highway ran east-northeast from Canton, Ohio to Alliance and east via Salem, crossing into Pennsylvania just east of East Palestine. From there it continued southeasterly to Beaver, crossing the Beaver River there and heading south along its left bank to Rochester and the Ohio River's right bank to Pittsburgh.\n", 'The Lincoln Highway entered Indiana on current US Route 30 to Fort Wayne. It turned northwest on modern U.S. Route 33 to Elkhart. It turned west on Lincoln Way through South Bend to U.S. Route 20. It followed US Route 20 to Rolling Prairie and continued on State Road 2 to Valparaiso where it rejoined US Route 30 to the Illinois state line.\n']

2. **Western Terminus**:

   - This specifies that the Lincoln Highway ends in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California.

   - This passage provides details about the highway's route within Indiana, which is part of its overall trajectory across the country.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - "The Lincoln Highway was planned in 1913 to run west to east across Indiana, including to South Bend and Fort Wayne."

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The Lincoln Highway is a historically significant roadway in the United States, recognized as the first transcontinental highway established in 1913. Its primary purpose was to connect the East and West coasts, facilitating automobile travel and promoting the development of road infrastructure across the nation.

1. **Eastern Terminus**:
   - The Lincoln Highway begins at Times Square in New York City. This location was chosen by the Lincoln Highway Association, led by entrepreneur Carl G. Fisher, as a symbolic starting point for the highway, representing the bustling urban center of the East.

2. **Western Terminus**:
   - The highway stretches across the country and concludes at Lincoln Park in San Francisco, California. This endpoint signifies the western reach of the highway, connecting it to the Pacific coast.

3. **Route Details**:
   - The highway traverses various states and landscapes, including a significant route through Indiana. In Indiana, it follows current U.S. Route 30 to Fort Wayne, then turns northwest on U.S. Route 33 to Elkhart, and continues west on Lincoln Way through South Bend to U.S. Route 20. This detailed routing illustrates how the Lincoln Highway was integrated into the existing road network.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - The planning and establishment of the Lincoln Highway in 1913 were pivotal in American transportation history. It was designed to alleviate railroad congestion and promote automobile travel, reflecting the growing importance of personal vehicles in American society.

5. **Cultural Impact**:
   - The Lincoln Highway is not just a physical route; it represents a cultural milestone in the United States, symbolizing the desire for national unity and accessibility. Its establishment marked a significant shift in how Americans traveled and connected with one another across vast distances.

### Conclusion:
The Lincoln Highway's historical significance, geographical orientation, and cultural impact are essential for understanding its role in American history. By recognizing its eastern terminus in New York City and its western terminus in San Francisco, along with its route through various states, we can appreciate the highway's legacy as a pioneering roadway that shaped the future of transportation in the United States.

### Answer:
The Lincoln Highway begins in Times Square, New York City, and ends in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California.

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. **Expert Discussion on the Lincoln Highway's Beginning and Ending Points**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The Lincoln Highway was established in 1913 as the first road to span the United States from coast to coast. Its western terminus is located in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California, while the eastern terminus is at the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway in Times Square, New York City. This foundational knowledge sets the stage for understanding the highway's significance in American transportation history.

**Expert 2: Geographic Route Analyst**
Building on the historical context, it's important to note the specific routes the Lincoln Highway took through various states. In Indiana, for example, it began at the Illinois state line and traveled eastward through towns like Fort Wayne and South Bend before reaching the Ohio state line. The highway's alignment has changed over the years, particularly in the early 20th century, as it adapted to new road standards and infrastructure developments.

**Expert 3: Infrastructure Development Expert**
I agree with the geographic route analyst but would like to emphasize the evolution of the Lincoln Highway's route. Initially, it followed a more direct path, but as urban areas developed, the highway was realigned to accommodate growing populations and traffic. For instance, in Indiana, the highway was moved south in the 1920s to follow what is now known as Old US 30, which reflects the ongoing adjustments made to improve accessibility and safety.

**Expert 4: Cultural Impact Scholar**
While the technical aspects of the highway's route are crucial, we should also consider its cultural significance. The Lincoln Highway was not just a means of transportation; it represented a vision of connectivity across America. The choice of terminus points—Times Square and Lincoln Park—symbolizes the link between urban centers and the American frontier spirit. This cultural narrative enriches our understanding of the highway's role in shaping American identity.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement:**
- **Agreement:** All experts concur that the Lincoln Highway spans from San Francisco to New York City and that it underwent various changes in its route over time.
- **Disagreement:** The emphasis on certain aspects varies. The historical context specialist focuses on the highway's inception and terminus points, while the geographic route analyst and infrastructure development expert highlight the specific routes and changes over time. The cultural impact scholar brings a different perspective by emphasizing the highway's broader significance beyond mere geography.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The Lincoln Highway serves as a vital artery in American history, connecting the East and West coasts and facilitating the movement of people and goods. Its route, beginning at the Illinois state line in Indiana and extending to the Ohio state line, reflects the highway's adaptability to changing infrastructure and urban development. The highway's cultural significance, represented by its terminus points, underscores its role in shaping American identity and connectivity.

In summary, the Lincoln Highway's journey from San Francisco to New York City is not just a tale of roads and routes; it is a narrative of American ambition, innovation, and cultural evolution. This multifaceted understanding enhances our appreciation of the highway's legacy and its ongoing impact on American society.

In the early 1920s, the Lincoln Highway was moved farther south between Valparaiso and Fort Wayne, to what is now known mostly as Old US\xa030, passing through Plymouth and Warsaw. The route became SR\xa02 from Ohio state line to South Bend, SR\xa01 from South Bend to Michigan state line. Then in 1924, the sections of the road that was part of the original Lincoln Highway was paved. The next few years the rest of the route was paved across Indiana, then in 1937 US\xa033 was created.
', 'The western end of the Lincoln Highway in Indiana was at the Illinois state line. The Lincoln Highway headed east passing through Dyer, still heading east the Lincoln Highway headed north around Schererville. Leaving US\xa030 and heading east, running one mile north of US\xa030, through Merrillville. East of Merrillville Lincoln Highway rejoins US\xa030, before leaving US\xa030 west of Valparaiso.
', 'Lincoln Highway in Indiana
', 'Nebraska Highway 31 is a highway in Nebraska. The southern terminus is near Louisville at an intersection with Nebraska Highway 50. The northern terminus is near Kennard at an intersection with U.S. Highway 30. The highway serves as a main north–south highway in the western portion of the Omaha Metro Area.
', 'The Lincoln Highway was planned in 1913 to run west to east across Indiana, including to South Bend and Fort Wayne. In 1915, the highway opened and passed through downtown Fort Wayne on its route through Indiana, and was assigned the designation of Main Market route number 2 in 1917. Further designations saw the route become SR\xa02 from the Illinois state line to Valparaiso, SR\xa044 Valparaiso to Fort Wayne and SR\xa02 from Fort Wayne to the Ohio state line. In the early 1920s, the Lincoln Highway was moved south between Valparaiso and Fort Wayne, to what is now known mostly as Old US\xa030, passing through Plymouth and Warsaw. A section of US\xa030 in Dyer known as the "ideal section" of the Lincoln Highway was opened in 1923 and rebuilt in the 1990s. In 1924, the sections of the road that were part of the original Lincoln Highway was paved, followed by the paving of the rest of US 30, which was commissioned in 1926. In 1927, a small realignment between Hanna and SR\xa029 (current US\xa035) took place. During the 1950s, US 30 in Fort Wayne was rerouted to Coliseum Boulevard, constructed as a "circumurban" highway to bypass Fort Wayne. But this "circumurban" route became an urban highway in its own right. In 1998, US\xa030 in Fort Wayne was again rerouted onto I-69 and I-469, bypassing most of Fort Wayne and New Haven on the north and east side of the two towns. The Coliseum Boulevard routing was assigned the SR 930 designation as a result, when INDOT could not give the route over to local control.
', 'The Lincoln Highway was the first route to follow the corridor of US\xa030 in Ohio. The Lincoln Highway was established in 1913, following the current route of SR\xa0309 and SR\xa081. Improvements and realignment to the highway were planned in 1917 and was to start in the spring of 1918. The route was built to relieve some of the railroad congestion. The Lincoln Highway realignment project was completed in 1939 and moved the Lincoln Highway to the modern US\xa030 corridor. The Lincoln Highway in Ohio became known as SR\xa05 between Indiana state line and Mansfield, SR\xa010 between Mansfield and Wooster, and SR\xa05 between Wooster and Pennsylvania. In 1925, the Federal Highway Association was established and one year later US\xa030 was established. US\xa030 followed the current route of SR\xa0309. US\xa030 eastern terminus in Ohio was relocated to the West Virginia state line, in 1928. The route became divided in 1932, with US\xa030N taking the current alignment of US\xa030 and US\xa030S taking the current alignment of SR\xa0309.
', 'This abandoned section of roadway was part of the original Lincoln Highway from 1913. It lies to the north of the Chicago Northwestern tracks which are immediately to the north of the Grand Junction Segment (see above). The Lincoln Highway route was moved north in eastern Greene County in 1914 so the Greene and Boone County segments of the highway would connect. The realignment also removed a couple of dangerous railroad crossings at the same time. This section of roadway survived that realignment, and remained part of the highway until 1922 when the right-of-way was shifted south of the railroad tracks and a new roadway was built. This realignment removed another railroad crossing at Grand Junction. There are three contributing resources to this historic district, two structures and one site. One of the structures is a concrete bridge that features concrete balustered guardrails. It was built by the Iowa Bridge Company in 1915 for $1,339. It replaced an older wooden span. A partially buried concrete driveway culvert is the other structure, and a section of the abandoned dirt roadway is the site. The roadway was never paved. The historic district is located on a farm and the former roadway and bridge are still used to move farm machinery.
', 'In 1913, the Lincoln Highway Association, headed by entrepreneur Carl G. Fisher, chose the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway (at the southeast corner of Times Square) to be the Eastern Terminus of the Lincoln Highway. This was the first road across the United States, which originally spanned coast-to-coast through 13 states to its western terminus in Lincoln Park in San Francisco, California.
', "As defined in 1913, the Lincoln Highway ran east-northeast from Canton, Ohio to Alliance and east via Salem, crossing into Pennsylvania just east of East Palestine. From there it continued southeasterly to Beaver, crossing the Beaver River there and heading south along its left bank to Rochester and the Ohio River's right bank to Pittsburgh.
", 'The Lincoln Highway entered Indiana on current US Route 30 to Fort Wayne. It turned northwest on modern U.S. Route 33 to Elkhart. It turned west on Lincoln Way through South Bend to U.S. Route 20. It followed US Route 20 to Rolling Prairie and continued on State Road 2 to Valparaiso where it rejoined US Route 30 to the Illinois state line.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the Lincoln Highway's route, its historical context, and its terminus points. Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Key Extracted Information:

1. **Historical Context and Planning**:
   - The Lincoln Highway was planned in 1913 to run from the Illinois state line to the Ohio state line, passing through significant locations such as Fort Wayne and South Bend in Indiana.
   - It was the first road to follow the corridor of US 30 in Ohio and was established to relieve railroad congestion.

2. **Route Details**:
   - The highway began at the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway in New York City (Times Square) as its eastern terminus.
   - The western terminus was located in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California.
   - In Indiana, the Lincoln Highway entered via US Route 30, passed through Fort Wayne, and continued to Valparaiso before rejoining US Route 30 to the Illinois state line.

3. **Designations and Changes**:
   - The highway underwent various designations, including Main Market route number 2 and state route designations (SR 2, SR 44).
   - The route was realigned multiple times, particularly in the early 20th century, to improve safety and efficiency.

4. **Geographical and Structural Changes**:
   - The highway's route included significant geographical features and urban areas, which influenced its design and construction.
   - Sections of the highway were paved in the 1920s, and further improvements were made in subsequent decades.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Historical Development**:
   - By analyzing the historical context of the Lincoln Highway, the model can learn how infrastructure development is influenced by socio-economic factors, such as the need to alleviate railroad congestion. This understanding can enhance causal reasoning about the relationship between transportation infrastructure and economic growth.

2. **Route Planning and Changes**:
   - The information about the highway's route changes and designations provides insight into how logistical considerations (like safety and efficiency) can lead to realignments. This can improve the model's ability to infer the consequences of planning decisions in urban development.

3. **Geographical Influence**:
   - The geographical details of the highway's route through various states and cities can help the model understand how physical geography impacts transportation planning. This can enhance logical inference regarding the interaction between geography and infrastructure.

4. **Temporal Changes**:
   - The timeline of the highway's construction and realignment offers a framework for understanding how historical events shape current infrastructure. This temporal aspect can improve the model's ability to reason about cause and effect over time.

5. **Integration of Multiple Factors**:
   - The consolidation of information regarding historical, geographical, and logistical factors allows the model to develop a more nuanced understanding of complex systems, improving its overall reasoning capabilities.

By synthesizing these elements, the model can better grasp the interconnectedness of historical events, geographical features, and infrastructural changes, leading to enhanced causal reasoning and logical inference skills.

question:
where does the lincoln highway begin and end
answer:
Reasoning process:
The Lincoln Highway is one of the earliest transcontinental highways in the United States, established in 1913. It was designed to connect the East and West coasts of the country. The highway traditionally begins in Times Square, New York City, which represents the eastern terminus. From there, it stretches across various states and landscapes, ultimately reaching its western terminus in San Francisco, California. This route was significant in promoting automobile travel and the development of road infrastructure in the U.S.

Answer:
The Lincoln Highway begins in Times Square, New York City, and ends in San Francisco, California.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The Lincoln Highway, established in 1913, is recognized as one of the earliest transcontinental highways in the United States, designed to facilitate travel between the East and West coasts. 

1. **Historical Context and Planning**:
   - The highway was initially planned to connect the Illinois state line to the Ohio state line, passing through key locations in Indiana, such as Fort Wayne and South Bend. This planning was influenced by the need to alleviate congestion on railroads, showcasing how transportation infrastructure evolves in response to economic demands.

2. **Route Details**:
   - The eastern terminus of the Lincoln Highway is at Times Square, New York City, while the western terminus is in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California. The route traverses various states, reflecting the geographical diversity of the U.S. In Indiana, it follows US Route 30, indicating how existing roadways were integrated into the highway system.

3. **Designations and Changes**:
   - Over the years, the highway has undergone multiple designations (e.g., Main Market route number 2, SR 2, SR 44) and realignments to enhance safety and efficiency. This highlights the dynamic nature of infrastructure planning, where logistical considerations can lead to significant changes in route design.

4. **Geographical and Structural Changes**:
   - The highway's alignment through urban areas and significant geographical features illustrates the impact of physical geography on transportation planning. The paving of sections in the 1920s and subsequent improvements reflect ongoing efforts to adapt to increasing automobile traffic.

This holistic view enhances the model's ability to reason about complex systems and infer relationships between cause and effect.

### Answer:
The Lincoln Highway begins at Times Square in New York City and ends at Lincoln Park in San Francisco, California. It was established to connect the East and West coasts and has undergone various changes and realignments throughout its history, reflecting the evolving needs of transportation infrastructure in the United States.

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The Lincoln Highway is recognized as one of the earliest transcontinental highways in the United States, established in 1913. It was designed to connect the East and West coasts of the country, facilitating automobile travel and the development of road infrastructure. 

1. **Eastern Terminus**: The Lincoln Highway traditionally begins at the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway in Times Square, New York City. This specific location serves as the official eastern terminus of the highway, emphasizing its historical significance as a starting point for cross-country travel.

2. **Western Terminus**: The highway extends across various states and landscapes, ultimately reaching its western terminus in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California. This endpoint is crucial for understanding the highway's full route across the United States.

3. **Route through Indiana**: The Lincoln Highway enters Indiana on current US Route 30, passing through Fort Wayne and other towns before rejoining US Route 30 at the Illinois state line. This detailed routing through Indiana highlights the highway's importance in connecting different regions.

4. **Designations and Changes**: Over the years, the Lincoln Highway has undergone various designations and realignments. It was designated as Main Market route number 2 in 1917 and later as SR 2 and SR 44 in Indiana. Understanding these designations provides context for the highway's evolution and its impact on local infrastructure.

5. **Realignment and Paving**: The highway has seen multiple realignments and paving efforts, particularly in the 1920s, 1950s, and 1990s. These changes reflect the ongoing development of the highway system and its adaptation to modern transportation needs.

By integrating this knowledge, the model can enhance its understanding of the Lincoln Highway's historical significance, geographical endpoints, and the changes it has undergone, thereby reducing the likelihood of inaccuracies or model illusions related to this topic.

**Answer:**
The Lincoln Highway begins at the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway in Times Square, New York City, and ends in Lincoln Park, San Francisco, California. It runs across various states, including a significant route through Indiana, where it follows current US Route 30. The highway has undergone various designations and realignments since its establishment in 1913, reflecting its historical importance and the evolution of road infrastructure in the United States.

This section of roadway survived that realignment, and remained part of the highway until 1922 when the right-of-way was shifted south of the railroad tracks and a new roadway was built. This realignment removed another railroad crossing at Grand Junction. There are three contributing resources to this historic district, two structures and one site. One of the structures is a concrete bridge that features concrete balustered guardrails. It was built by the Iowa Bridge Company in 1915 for $1,339. It replaced an older wooden span. A partially buried concrete driveway culvert is the other structure, and a section of the abandoned dirt roadway is the site. The roadway was never paved. The historic district is located on a farm and the former roadway and bridge are still used to move farm machinery.
In 1913, the Lincoln Highway Association, headed by entrepreneur Carl G. Fisher, chose the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway (at the southeast corner of Times Square) to be the Eastern Terminus of the Lincoln Highway. This was the first road across the United States, which originally spanned coast-to-coast through 13 states to its western terminus in Lincoln Park in San Francisco, California.
As defined in 1913, the Lincoln Highway ran east-northeast from Canton, Ohio to Alliance and east via Salem, crossing into Pennsylvania just east of East Palestine. From there it continued southeasterly to Beaver, crossing the Beaver River there and heading south along its left bank to Rochester and the Ohio River's right bank to Pittsburgh.
The Lincoln Highway entered Indiana on current US Route 30 to Fort Wayne. It turned northwest on modern U.S. Route 33 to Elkhart. It turned west on Lincoln Way through South Bend to U.S. Route 20. It followed US Route 20 to Rolling Prairie and continued on State Road 2 to Valparaiso where it rejoined US Route 30 to the Illinois state line.
__answers__: Times Square in New York City
from Times Square in New York City west to Lincoln Park in San Francisco
